title: What do underdeveloped parts of your country look like? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, the best example could be some part of so called “distal countryside” despite Czech Republic is relatively small country, there are areas and municipalities quite far from all bigger towns/cities, with quite underdeveloped transport infrastructure and often on the edge of the state or regions. Czech Republic/Czechia  I read a very nice quote several years ago. It was something like “If you wanna know how rich/poor or how developed/undeveloped is some country. You should visit the most distant village.” I recently comeback from Broumov area in Náchod district. One of the most distant part of the country (relatively “isolated” by rocks from the rest of the state) located near borders with Poland.  Location in the CZ  Map of the area Broumov town, the biggest municipality in the area - 7 444 ppl. It´s quite ordinary small Czech town. Market square with shops, several supermarkets, library, town museum, gallery, 2 kindergardens, 3 elementary schools, one high school,foster home, 2 post offices, sport center, soccer and athletic field, 2 public sport clubs, sport hall, small hospital and small clinic, wellness, retirement house, couple of restaurants, pubs and cafés, railway and bus station, monastery, several churches, petting zoo, police station and firefighter station, brewery    Rocks and hills almost isolate this area from rest of the state.  There are several small villages around. Broumov town is center of this area and many inhibitans work in the town. Božanov village - 362 ppl  Local countryside scenery  Heřmánkovice village - 495 ppl  Another local scenery  View from rocks to Křinice village - 431 ppl  So It could be really cool live there but my work is connected to major cities for now. Althought this area is located quite far from all bigger towns and It's distant countryside there is everything for ordinary life. Public transport  Kindergarden and Elementary school in Jetřichov village  Local restaurants and pubs  Local grocer's  Quite calm place but really cool…

Some dangerous neighborough in Italy, mostly from the southern region of Italy, that have a strong Mafia presence, the government always ignored the south and its problems. For example gdp pro-capita in the norther region is around 35K € (Tuscany: 29K , Lombardy: 37K, Trento: 39K) while in the souther region is around 17K (Sicily 16K, Calabria 14K). So poorest part of some city can be quite hardcore… Scampia, NaplesThis zone is one of the biggest drug-pushing marketplace in Europe, with its famous building “le vele”, that now in 2020 they will be demolished. This zone improved a lot in the past 10 years, but stil there’s a lot of criminality and poverty.   2. ZEN, Palermo This zone was build in the ’70 as all public housing, since then it gained the popularity of one of the most degraded zone of Italy, with a huge mafia presence. Once national TV tried to get in to show how degraded was the area and they got aggressed by the population with even shotguns (nobody was injured).     3. Arghillà, Reggio Calabria Another highly poor zone with public housing and lots of mafia and criminality   4. Tor bella monaca, Rome Another critical zone made with public housing, where many different ethnicities live toughether and lots of criminality.   This is when police arrested a guy: they got surrounded other people trying to free the guy.

upvoters.user_id: Yashvardhan Singh Solanki(कुंवर यशवर्धन सिंह सोलंकी)

response.answer_text: Out of all towns, cities and villages in my country, one village that consistently tops the list of deprivation in England is Jaywick, Essex  Originally a salt marsh, the area was first used to construct a Martello Tower in 1809 as a defence in case of French invasion. The area was later purchased by Frank Stedman in 1928 to create a cheap seaside resort, with a focus on providing holiday homes for East End Londoner residents. Plots of land were sold as low as £25, and as a result the resort boomed during the Great Depression. The original estate was even shaped like a radiator grill, and streets were names after Car vendors, as a result of the automotive boom that was happening at the time.  By the end of World War 2 business had halted and there was pressure by the local council to demolish the area. However demand for housing had increased following the Blitz, and many Londoners took up permanent residence in the plotland. There was a long dispute which was settled in 1970 with the residents allowed to stay in their holiday homes, which by now had begun to decay, with a mains sewage system not even installed until 1978. The development continued to decline after the closure of a Butlins resort in 1983, and today over 40% of residents are unable to work and 60% of working age people receive benefits. Most recently a picture of the town was used in an attack ad in the 2018 US Elections. The picture used was this:  There was widespread criticism by the town’s residents, and eventually the creator of the image, Nick Stella, apologised. To be clear, it is mostly the eastern, original half of the village that is so depraved, while other parts such as Tudor Estate, while not a utopia, are at least tolerable.  Home in Tudor Estate. After a Channel 5 documentary many Tudor Estate residents asked the Royal Mail to remove “Jaywick” from their mailing address.  Typical street in Jaywick.  One of the more depraved areas of Jaywick. The area is prone to flooding, with the North Sea flood of 1953 killing 35 people.  The Mermaid Inn, abandoned after a fire.  The Martello Tower of Jaywick, renovated in 2005 as an art exhibition.  The Tower pre renovation.  A house in Jaywick.  Jaywick: Then vs Now.

There are some UN -developed areas of Switzerland that look like Greenland:  This picture is from March 31st 2019. Typical spring weather on those alpine pastures….. This scenery does not look all that different, the ice-field in the center never melts, at least not this year, despite lowland temperatures now going to approach mid-100s Fahrenheit for a few days. But this here is the highest, most remote area of the Swiss Alps. Let’s look at some UNDER developed areas!  Near La Brevine, canton of Neuchatel. This is a very remote area for Switzerland. Very thinly populated, the town has some 700 people. It sits at roughly 1000 m above sea level and it has this wide-open horizons that are seldom seen in an otherwise densely populated and vertically-oriented country.  But you do not have to go to “Swiss Siberia” to see countryside that is pretty much unchanged since medieval times. This secluded spot is only a 3 hour hike away from my flat, by car it takes a mere 30 minutes to get here. Again, we are at roughly 1000 m above sea level, just 40 km south of the very urban, industrialized city of Basel. This pastures have been cleared by the year 1200 or so, when medieval population increase required additional land being brought into production. They used to belong to a small monastery that has been abandoned a long time ago. The climate of the Jura mountains is rough, usually very wet and stormy. This seemingly small and hilly-looking range is actually a very formidable obstacle for road building. Those “hills” hide vertical cliffs, rocky terrain and steep ascends beneath an inpenetrable forest canopy, that yield to wild, narrow canyons sometimes hundred of meters deep. There are very few good passes through there, which are almost as high as the ridges. Up here, you can encounter mountain goat, deer, lynx and European wildcats, wild boars and hares and a very rich birdlife as well. There are preparations being made to re-introduce the wisent, “European bison” - but cattle ranchers are not happy about that.

I’m not sure if Lithuania has parts that would be considered “underdeveloped”. We have urban areas, small towns, countryside, forests, lakes and, more recently, suburbs. Some parts of some cities are “underdeveloped” but it’s less obvious than the way it works in massive countries of inequality like the US, India, China, Brazil or South Africa. This is what development looks like in Lithuania, according to EEA (European Environment Agency) in 2008. A lot has changed since then but the idea is still the same: the redder the area, the more developed it is. As you can see, much of Lithuania’s landscape is forested or rural.  However, much of the population is concentrated in the cities. Lithuania has 2.8 million residents as of early 2020 Largest cities or towns in Lithuania  Half of Lithuania lives in the top 10 cities and towns. So, this is what “underdeveloped” looks like in Lithuania. Chances are, if you are in Lithuania but not in a city or town, your view will look something like this: Typical countryside   Lithuania’s forests   Baltic Coast (Curonian Spit and Sventoji)   Lakes   Ancient capital of Lithuania, Kernave   Don’t forget, Lithuania is more often cold than not. Winters often add to the peaceful atmosphere:   You may find some villages and towns in Lithuania that aren’t in a great shape. I’m actually not aware of any, because I grew up in Panevezys and have visited the country extensively but haven’t really seen anything “alarming”. Feel free to correct me if I’m wrong.

BELGIUM. Belgium is a small country, so there are no parts of the country where it’s difficult to travel to. It’s a highly populated, there are no big woods or regions where no one lives. underdeveloped in Belgium means cities or regions where the industry collapsed. People moved away from those cities or became poor, so there were no investments anymore. A famous example is : DOEL  It’s a little town near De schelde, an important river for the economy of Belgium. in 1960, The port of Antwerp made plans to expand, which would mean that the town will dissapear in the future. Because of this plans, slowly the town had become dead : the local people decide to leave, nobody wanted to invest in the local economy. Now Doel is known as a dead town. Eventually, the port didn’t expand, but it was already to late… Now, there is a kind of ‘’dark tourism’’. People find it funny ro visit the town. It’s a little bit scary. Everything is empty, but the houses, the Streets, etc… are still there. No one cleaned it up.   images : google

I live in Suriname, Just a fraction of the country has been developed. Other than that you can find yourself in the wild amazonian rainforest if you drive a few hours away from the capital city, Paramaribo. Approximately 94.7% – about 14.8 million hectares- of Suriname is covered by dense tropical rainforest. You can also find many native american, and maroon villages far from any settlement on the side of rivers. Those villages are only navigable by boat and air. And here’s what that looks like:

I live in Sweden, in a region that is considered underdeveloped, or perhaps more “suffering from lack of cohesion” in infrastructure - glesbygd, is the Swedish expression. We get various rebates because of it, and real estate is cheap here because of it. Logically, because there are no jobs. It looks like this:             I don’t mind. In case you worry, there are cities here, too. The biggest one has 50.000 inhabitants. Big enough for a university and a cinema; just the one though, with nothing else within a radius of 200 kilometres:         And when you go into the villages, life looks like this:

For people who want to promote their country and show natural uninhabited parks or natural beauty of the country are completely missing the point and fail to anwser the question either on purpose or not (I don’t know which one is worse). The question asks for underdeveloped areas, which means that you need to show/describe/write about areas in your country where there is human habitation and economic activity, but it is underdeveloped! I hate when Quorans use the platform to promote their own country in a false way, and contribute little to nothing to the subject at hand. Please lets remain professional. Here is a map of areas in purchasing power from Poland:  100 = average earnings for Poland.

Hey! Let’s take a look at Liberia’s map, From west Africa. It is ranked one of the poorest countries in the globe, overall, the entire country is considered an underdeveloped nation.  So far let’s take a look at some remote part of the country. West Point Community 2. Clara Town Community   There’s a lot to see out here, but just a few to share,, Thank you for reading,,; Images: Google (company)

Here in the Dominican Republic the less developed parts look really bad since we are a third world country and with an incredible social inequality you can see a great contrast. First this like developer area look    And this like underdeveloped look
At least those photo’s are from the poorest municipalities, the big cities such as Rotterdam and Amsterdam have actual Ghetto’s.

I think that all countries have their least developed areas, just like in my country, Romania .. we have many poor and dangerous neighborhoods. In Bucharest, the most dangerous place is a neighborhood of gypsies, called Ferentari.
